– with its 50m high chalk cliffs is the northernmost place in East Germany, is situated on Rügen north of Putgarten.

The size and shape of the island provides 574km of coastline. The beaches are generally excellent for bathing. In the main season dogs are only allowed on designated
), but there are plenty of these. Also on the island are a few nudist (

The language mostly spoken on Rügen is German, but most people speak some English, although perhaps fewer than in other parts of Germany. The island was for more than 40 years part of East Germany, when the first foreign language taught in schools was Russian.
You should get by with

Chalk cliffs in the Jasmund National Park, view Ernst-Moritz-Arndt

with connection from Frankfurt, Munich, Stuttgart and Cologne is about 90km from Rügen.
From the A20 then B96, you can get in by car along Germany's longest bridge from
on the German mainland, or you can take the ferry from
There is also a regional train connection from Stralsund to Sassnitz and Ostseebad Binz, some long distance trains travel to Ostseebad Binz.
Three major ship-owners operates ferries to and from Sassnitz:
There is also a cable ferry from Stahlbrode near

As well as the coast line with excellent beaches and spectacular cliffs there are some beautiful woodlands and wetlands. This is a great location for wetland bird watching, notably the large flocks of cranes.

value: directions=B96 from Mukran or from Sassnitz. In Bergen auf Rügen, take the L301 to Putbus. In Putbus, follow Bahnhofstraße from Circus. The railway station is at the end of the road.
hours=First train from Putbus around 08:00, last train around 19:30

content=During the GDR era, the narrow-gauge railway "Rasender Roland" was an important link between Putbus and Göhren, where the steam-hauled trains provided both passenger and goods services. The railway is still a part of the local traffic system and a journey is an excellent way of transportation. There are several nice places to see along the railway, for example the hunting "lodge" (read: "castle") Granitz. You can board the train from any station along the line. Group tickets on offer.
directions=Take the B96. At Bergen auf Rügen, take the L301 to Ramitz. Drive N for Bubkewitz, where you take off W to Zirmoisel.
content=Whether you are an experienced rider or a beginner, this establishment has something for everyone, for example adventure on horseback or picnic. The center has also a flat for rental.
directions=Take the B96. Lietzow is at the road between Sagard and Bergen.
content=If you already know how to surf, you can rent all you need from Wassersportschule Timpeltu. If you cannot surf, they can teach you how. The school also has smaller yachts and canoes for rent.
content=The company Sanfte Reisen offers flights with a hot air balloon. Departure, time and price on request.
directions=From Stralsund: B96 to Bergen, then L196 to Kluptow and L293 to Prora. From Sassnitz/Mukran, taake the L29 to Prora.
content=If you are into diving can rent the equipment here. If you do not know how to dive, they can teach you. Tauchen Rügen also arranges guided tours to wrecks.

content=Bikes can be rented in almost every place, daily rates start as low as €5. You can get your bike delivered to your holiday appt or hotel. A large, and still to improve, network of bike trails offers sceneries beyond the jammed main roads. The holiday home Birkengrund not only offers accommodation for rent, but also bikes. They have several packages including bikes and accommodation. Guide´d tours on request.
directions=From Stralsund: B96 to Bergen, then road 196 to Zirkow. From Sassnitz: L29 to Prora, then L293 to Karow and road 196 to Zirkow
content=WSC Rügen offers classes in water skiing and wakeboard. You may rent per hour, week or season.
directions=Take the B96. In Teschenhagen, take the L291 through Sehlen to Karnitz.
content=The golf centre in Karnitz has two courses, 9 and 18 holes.

Rügen is an island, which you can tell when you walk into a restaurant. Seafood is omnipresent and usually very fresh. Try a
, a sliced bread roll filled with smoked (
) or pickled herring and vegetables. The Germans are crazy about asparagus, so during season, do not miss out. You will also find in the region products made from sea-buckthorn (
) such as fruit juice (served hot or cold), jam and flavoured ice cream.

The local sea-buckthorn (sanddorn) fruit juice is best hot.

Although brewed just of the island in
beer is readily available and well worth a few glasses.

Due to the island's popularity over the years, it is easy to find accommodation at all price and comfort levels. The most common accommodation is various forms of holiday apartments, a practical and cheap way to stay. If you prefer to stay in hotels or hostels, there is plenty to choose from. A double in a hotel is around €80-120/night, breakfast included. A holiday flat, a
, starts at around  €20 p.p. and night.

When walking near the cliffs, be careful near the edges as they tend to overhand the actual cliff face and are subject to collapse.

Although rare there is a risk of coming across wild boar, keep your distance and tread with respect.
